content.definition:
adj. Young and inexperienced; immature.
The student was too callow to know he was being fooled.

n. A person living during the same period as another.
Martha Jane Canary, known as “Calamity Jane,” and Annie Oakley were contemporaries.
adj. Existing or occurring at the same time.
The rise in fuel costs was contemporary with the demand for alternative fuels.

adj. Doubtful of the sincerity of others’ motives; skeptical.
People become cynical about those who make promises but don’t keep them.
n. Cynic
Even though many clients have lied to her, the attorney has not become a cynic.

n. A ruler with absolute power or tyrannical control over a group of people.
Divided government makes rule by a despot less likely.
adj. Despotic
The Declaration of Independence of the United States asserts the government’s right to overthrow a despotic ruler.

v. 1. To pronounce clearly.
In speech class we learn to enunciate our words.
2. To state; to announce.
The president enunciated her objectives for the coming year in her State of the Union address to Congress.

n. Anything that gets in the way; an obstacle.
After the hurricane, fallen trees were impediments to traffic in our neighborhood.

v. 1. To make poor.
Uncontrolled spending can impoverish a person.
2. To take away.
Continual overfarming impoverishes the soil.
adj. Impoverished: The Peace Corps is an agency of the United States government that sends volunteers to improve living standards in impoverished areas of the world.

adj. Indulging in ease; avoiding exertion; lazy.
Being in the torrid heat of the tropical sun makes one feel indolent.
n. Indolence: His failure to reach his goal certainly cannot be attributed to indolence.

adj. Showing sound judgment; wise.
My grandmother’s sagacious advice has guided me many times over the years.
n. Sagacity: I was surprised when she questioned the sagacity of my plan to climb the mountain.

adj. Worldly; not connected with a church or religion.
The choir included a few secular songs in the memorial service.

v. 1. To think about or make guesses.
As we waited, we speculated about whether he’d keep his promise and show up.
2. To engage in a risky business venture.
She lost a great deal of money when she speculated in the stock market last year.

n. Conflict or struggle.
The strife between the two families has existed for a few years now.

v. To show great respect for.
Asian cultures venerate their ancestors long after they have died.

adj. 1. Ravenous; desiring and eating a large amount of food.
We arrived back from our hike with voracious appetites.
2. Greatly eager.
Danyal has been a voracious reader since childhood.

v. To get smaller, dimmer, or weaker; to near an end.
When interest in sitcoms waned, the television networks switched to reality shows.

pages.name: Understanding Meanings
pages.subheading: Read the following sentences. If the word is in bold and used correctly, write C. If the word is used incorrectly, write a new sentence using the word correctly.

content.question: A voracious creature is very hungry.
A sagacious person is difficult to rouse to action.
content.answer: A sagacious person gives wise and thoughtful advice.

content.question: A secular group is one concerned primarily with spiritual or religious matters.
content.answer: A secular group is not connected with religion or the church.

content.question: Strife between people is a condition of tranquility.
content.answer: Strife is a conflict or struggle, not tranquility.

content.question: To speculate is to make a precarious monetary transaction.
content.answer: To speculate is to think about or make guesses, or to engage in a risky business venture.

content.question: A callow person is someone who is easily frightened.
content.answer: A callow person is young and inexperienced.

content.question: To venerate someone is to hold that person in high regard.
A despot is a person who avoids the company of others.
content.answer: A despot is a ruler with absolute or tyrannical control.

content.question: Indolence is a state of indecision.
content.answer: Indolence is a state of laziness or avoidance of exertion.

content.question: To enunciate a principle is to express it clearly.
Contemporaries are people living in the same area of the world.
content.answer: Contemporaries are people living during the same period as another.

content.question: To wane is to go from place to place in aimless fashion.
content.answer: To wane means to become smaller, dimmer, or weaker; to near an end.

content.question: An impediment is a barrier or obstruction.
A cynic is a person who is easily deceived.
content.answer: A cynic is a person who doubts the sincerity of others’ motives.

content.question: To be impoverished is to lack sufficient money for one’s needs.

content.name: Ideas That Endure
passage: The present educators are those whose lessons are still remembered centuries after their deaths. Among this select group, few stand higher than the Chinese sage Confucius. He was the first to enunciate the Golden Rule—treat others as you would have them treat you.

Confucius was born into a noble but impoverished family in 551 BCE in what is now the province of Shantung. His father died when he was three; as a young man he worked as a herder and storekeeper in order to support himself and his widowed mother. Unable to pay for a formal education, he became a voracious reader whose wide and lively learning soon earned him a formidable reputation as a scholar.

Hired as a tutor to the sons of the wealthy, he decided to open his own school. Willingness to learn was the only requirement; lack of money was no impediment. Because Confucius required the wealthier parents to pay for the education of the poorer students, many of his students were one and the same, thereby adding to his reputation as a man of learning and moral character. Almost all who knew Confucius extolled his virtues.

An exception to these admirers was Lao-tzu, a man whose writings are second only to those of Confucius in their impact on China. The two sages met when Confucius was in his early thirties. Lao-tzu was more than fifty years his senior. The older man was venerated as the founder of the religion of Taoism, although he thought the younger man callow. This judgment is not surprising, for Lao-tzu’s concerns were spiritual, while Confucius’ thoughts were focused largely on secular matters. For example, Confucius declined to discuss whether the soul survives the death of the body. His position was that because one cannot understand the meaning of life, there is no point in speculating about the mystery of death.

Contemporary with a time of great unrest, Confucius’s concern had always been with such practical questions as how to achieve good government and how best to conduct relations within the family and between individuals. His answer to both questions was 'li'—translated as 'good manners.' That meant those in authority should show respect to those beneath them. Confucius’ ideas were particularly appropriate for his time because during that period, China lacked a strong central government. Despotic warlords ruled China, and their constant strife and widespread vice brought disorder and misery to the common people. In the words of one of Confucius’ contemporaries: 'The world had fallen into decay, and right principles had disappeared.'

As a result of his success with former pupils, Confucius was made a minister of justice in his native province of Lu. Not surprisingly, he proved to be a sagacious administrator. As high officer, Confucius was able to practice and encourage others to do the same. In this way, he helped restore order in the land, all but eliminated crime, and gave the people of Lu a period of peace.

This happy state was short-lived. The ruler of Lu Province grew indolent and began taking advice from those who wanted to return to the old ways. They wanted more opportunity for personal enrichment. Confucius found his influence waning in the corrupting government of Lu. After four years in office, he was dismissed as a result of the maneuvers of jealous rivals. Now fifty-six, Confucius spent the next thirteen years traveling throughout China, hoping to find a ruler who would accept his guidance. Although he failed in this endeavor, there is no evidence that he ever became cynical.

Although Confucius did not put his principles into writing, groups of his followers passed on his teachings. These dealt with codes of conduct based on the belief that strong moral character is the basis of civilization and that inner goodness is reflected in outer behavior. Some three thousand principles of Confucius survive and became the basis of Chinese education for over two thousand years.

content.question: Why was Confucius not able to afford a formal education?
content.answer: Because he was born into an impoverished family and had to support his widowed mother.

content.question: Which detail in the passage suggests that Confucius was not an indolent youth?
content.answer: He worked as a herder and storekeeper and became a voracious reader to educate himself.

content.question: How did Confucius educate himself?
content.answer: He was a voracious reader and learned through wide and lively reading.

content.question: How might following the Golden Rule reduce strife?
content.answer: If people treat others with respect, as the Golden Rule advises, it may prevent strife and conflict.

content.question: What would be an appropriate description for the person who says that the Golden Rule is 'The one with the gold makes the rules'?
content.answer: That person might be seen as cynical, doubting the sincerity or fairness of others.

content.question: What evidence do we have that the followers of Confucius venerated him?
content.answer: They passed down his teachings and based Chinese education on them for over two thousand years.

content.question: What impediments did Confucius have to overcome as a young man?
content.answer: He had no money and had to support his family, yet he still pursued learning.

content.question: What were some of the differences in point of view between Confucius and Lao-tzu?
content.answer: Lao-tzu was focused on spiritual matters, while Confucius focused on secular and practical issues.

content.question: How do you know that Confucius and Lao-tzu were contemporaries?
content.answer: The passage states that the two sages met when Confucius was in his early thirties and Lao-tzu was older.

content.question: What contributed to Lao-tzu’s impression that Confucius was callow?
content.answer: Confucius focused on practical affairs instead of spiritual matters, which may have seemed immature to Lao-tzu.

content.question: What quality did Confucius and Lao-tzu share?
content.answer: They were both sagacious thinkers who influenced Chinese thought deeply.

content.question: Why was it unlikely that despotic rulers would appoint Confucius to a position of authority?
content.answer: Because Confucius promoted fairness, order, and morality, which contrasted with the interests of despotic rulers.

content.question: Why do you think interest in Confucius' teachings has not waned?
content.answer: Because his teachings on morality and order continue to resonate and guide people even today.
